Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Ambient-Pressure Plasma Degassing for Low Cost Vacuum Glass
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be to remove a barrier to commercialization of low-cost vacuum glass, a major building energy efficiency improvement. Universal use (unachievable but a useful point of reference) could reduce total U.S. energy use by 5% (about 4 quadrillion BTU/year), more than $15 billion/year at today?s natural gas prices, while adding minimal cost to building infrastructure. This disruptive technology will claim a large share of the new and retrofit building market. Rapid market penetration will be driven by the classic value proposition much better performance for the same cost, eliminating the need for government subsidy. In the near term, the customers will be manufacturers of high-end windows for use in homes around the world. Germany and Russia have their own vacuum glass development programs; a successful development will ensure the U.S. stays at the forefront.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aspires to demonstrate the feasibility of removing residual surface gases from the inside of vacuum glass assemblies using a room temperature process. This necessary manufacturing step is traditionally achieved using a high-temperature bakeout process, which eliminates the possibility of supplying tempered vacuum glass (25% of the market). Research will be performed on an ambient pressure plasma degassing process, which can be carried out at room temperature. Risks include 1) failure to prevent re-adsorption of moisture prior to sealing leading to longer cycle times and short product life, 2) arcing due to the presence of the metal foil seal, low-emissivity metal coatings, 3) varying pane sizes in the same machine, and 4) excessive cycle time and inert gas wastage leading to high cost. This project will build upon atmospheric pressure surface treatment research by the subawardee, the Center for Plasma-Aided Manufacturing at the University of Wisconsin at Madison.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project was conducted from July 2014 through June 2015 to investigate steps to extend the vacuum life of Vacuum Insulating Glass (VIG) units, most importantly, reducing the deleterious effect of outgassing of moisture from internal surfaces.

Moisture adsorbs on glass surfaces of vacuum glass components, and must be removed during the manufacturing process to preserve vacuum life. Traditional thermal bakeout requires heating the entire mass of glass to desorb this moisture. In contrast, plasma degassing treats the glass surface only, bombarding it with billions of ions. Plasma degassing is not new. Germany has been researching the use of plasma degassing in the manufacture of vacuum glass; however, they do this under vacuum, which is inefficient due to the extremely low density of bombarding ions. In contrast, this Phase II project used plasma at atmospheric pressure, which theoretically should be more efficient, due to a much higher density of ions. To our knowledge, the use of atmospheric pressure plasma for this purpose has not been attempted before.

The primary objective of this project was to determine the feasibility and cost-reduction potential of an atmospheric pressure plasma degassing system, operating at room-temperature, as an alternative to thermal bakeout. Such a plasma-based degassing system would be a key enabling technology for long life and low manufacturing cost of vacuum glass.

To summarize the progress during the life of the Phase I project:

  • Plasma Degassing Feasibility - This Phase I project achieved its primary objective, that is, it confirmed the technical feasibility of using plasma at ambient pressure to desorb moisture from the surfaces of glass panes and metal foil. Three independent methods were used to confirm this. Compared to thermal bakeout, plasma degassing appears to be significantly faster, more energy efficient and less costly.
  • Leak-free Welds – During this project, parameters of the welding process were tuned to reliably produce leak-free foil-to-glass welds, another key enabling technology for long life.
  • Needle Bearing Spacer – During this project, we learned how to incorporate a practical low-heat-loss pane spacer into our prototype vacuum windows. This novel low-loss spacer is the most important enabling technology for highly-insulating (that is, high R-value) performance.
  • Performance Milestone Achieved - During winter field testing, a prototype VIG with low-loss spacers demonstrated an insulating value of R-8. This is twice that of triple pane in the same test, and 2-1/2 times that of the only vacuum glass currently available on the market.

This project relied upon advances in atmospheric pressure surface treatment research by the University of Wisconsin at Madison and others.

The broader impacts of successful development of affordable vacuum glass are considerable. Buildings represent 40% of total U.S. energy consumption. Dual-pane insulating glass with Low-E coating, introduced in the 1980’s, was the last major efficiency improvement in windows, and is in near-universal use today. Likewise, vacuum insulating glass offers another major efficiency improvement; near-universal use could reduce total U.S. energy use by 5% (about 4 quadrillion BTU/year), more than $15 billion/year at today’s natural gas prices, while adding minimal cost to building infrastructure. Other benefits include lower greenhouse gas emissions and more comfortable buildings.
